ARTICLE.TITLE: Coronavirus: Prime Minister's announcement bitter-sweet for couple
ARTICLE.TEXT:
Alana Sayers and Jamie Conroy have already had to change their wedding date once before because of Covid-19, and the pair hope it can go ahead next Saturday.

The Government’s decision to extend the Covid-19 levels for 12 days is bitter-sweet for a couple wanting to marry in Invercargill next Saturday.

Jamie Conroy and Alana Sayers want to marry in front of family and friends but with Auckland staying at alert level 3, six invited guests living there will not be attending.

Sayers was hoping her sister, aunt, uncle and cousins, of Auckland, would be in Invercargill for the big day.

Within minutes of Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern announcing on Friday that Auckland would stay at level 3 and the rest of New Zealand at level 2 for 12 more days, Sayers received a message from her sister Rachel Sayers, of Auckland.

“That’s not what we wanted,” was Rachel’s opening sentence.

Alana Sayers said the wedding would be livestreamed for Auckland members of the family.

“At this stage we can still go ahead with the wedding.”

Rachel’s bridesmaid’s dress will be sent to her, if she wishes to wear it while watching the wedding.

An invited guest on the Gold Coast, unable to travel because of border closures, sent flowers to the couple recently wishing them a great day on August 22.

READ MORE:

* The Langlands Hotel opening likely delayed until 2022 because of Covid-19

* 'Covid hasn't cancelled love' in Southland

* Jamie Conroy confident he can bounce back in round two of NZ Touring Car Championship

* Invercargill race car driver Jamie Conroy wants to fuel himself with knowledge

* Good TRS debut for Conroy

* Invercargill driver Jamie Conroy books seat in Toyota series



The wedding has caused Sayers and Conroy many anxious moments as it was originally arranged for April 4 when New Zealand was in lockdown alert level 4.

“We then waited till level 1 to set a new date [August 22],” Sayers said.

“We couldn’t get married in September, Jamie’s sister is having a baby, my sister’s wedding is in October and there another wedding in November.”

Half of the 70 guests for the wedding next Saturday live outside Southland.

If alert levels had risen on Friday and it was not possible to hold a large gathering, the couple would have considered marrying in the presence of a celebrant and a witness only. A party with family and friends would have been held when possible, Sayers said.

“We’re not stressing too much, it’s something [Covid-19] we can’t control, just got to accept things,” Conroy said.

Sayers keeps a close eye on her health because she is immunocompromised with a rare kidney complaint.

When New Zealand went to alert level 3 in March, Sayers had to stop working as a receptionist at Harcourts, Invercargill, and stay home.

“I’m okay to work at level 2 but at level 3 I have to go home.”

Supplied The engagement ring Jamie Conroy made for his marriage proposal to Alana Sayers.

On top of disruptions to the wedding Conroy has had worrying news with the announcement that his employer, the Rio Tinto Group, was closing the Tiwai Point Aluminium Smelter next year.

He’s a diesel mechanic and auto electrician at the smelter.

His skills came in handy for when he made the engagement ring for Sayers. They got engaged on the top of a hill in Queenstown in August, 2018.

“It took me a year to make it [the ring],” Conroy said.

He made it in the couple’s garage.

To make the ring’s band, he melted down two 300-year-old Italian coins and a 200-year-old silver coin bought off Trade Me.

Conroy worked out measurements for the ring size by inspecting other rings owned by Sayers.

“I measured it off one of her other rings when she wasn’t looking.”
